search_result.title: Here are Delaware's most influential people in sports in 2024
search_result.text:
David Baylor: DIAA leader

Baylor was hired in July by the Delaware Department of Education to oversee the Delaware Interscholastic Athletic Association, which regulates middle and high school sports in Delaware and operates its state championship events. Baylor, who had been serving as the DIAA’s sportsmanship committee chairman, is a Navy veteran who served 23 years in the Delaware State Police, was director of human resources and training at NKS Distributors, then became Delaware City police chief and then its town manager. He was also player development coach for the University of Delaware football team. Among his major tasks as DIAA chief, Baylor said, were clarifying and simplifying DIAA regulations, especially regarding waiver requests involving player eligibility, transfers, transgender participation and Name/Image/Likeness opportunities for high school athletes.

Ryan Carty: University of Delaware football coach

Hired as University of Delaware football coach in December of 2021, Carty has guided the Blue Hens, the state’s most closely followed team, to two NCAA Division I Football Championship Subdivision playoff berths, its first in back-to-back years since Cary was back-up quarterback in 2003 and ’04. Delaware’s 9-4 2023 team was its winningest in 13 years. But Carty must now steer Delaware’s challenging climb to the Football Bowl Subdivision and its 2025 entrance to Conference USA.

search_result.title: Polytech's Kody Stevens comes back strong after injury
search_result.text:
Brad Myers

The News Journal





GEORGETOWN – On Jan. 7, when Kody Stevens' right knee locked up in a match against Caesar Rodney, the Polytech senior thought his wrestling season was over.

But Stevens underwent surgery, attacked his rehabilitation with fervor and returned by Feb. 3. On Saturday, he won the 126-pound title at the Henlopen Conference Wrestling Championships at Sussex Central.

"I probably won't be at the level I was before I got hurt," Stevens said of his chances going into next week's dual meet and individual state tournaments. "But just to know that I'm somewhere close to there and still competing for the top spot ... it makes me confident."

Stevens tore a meniscus in his right knee days before last year's conference meet, but endured the pain and finished second in the Henlopen and third at 120 pounds in the DIAA Individual Wrestling Championships. He underwent surgery to repair the tear in March, and was ready for the Panthers' football season in August.

But then disaster struck against Caesar Rodney.

"When we wrestled CR, my knee got locked up and I couldn't bend it because my meniscus got stuck," Stevens said. "The only way for it to bend was for me to have surgery."

Instead of being repaired again, which would have required a lengthy recovery, the meniscus was removed this time.

"When they take it out, it's a lot faster," said Stevens, who was one of four Polytech wrestlers to win a conference title Saturday. "I just have two small cuts in the back of my knee."

Top-ranked Smyrna rolled to the team title, piling up 284 points to easily outdistance Polytech (194½), Milford (177) and CR (156½). The Eagles really won it on Friday, when all 14 of their wrestlers reached the semifinals.

"That says a lot about the balance of our team. I'm really happy about that," Eagles coach Kurt Howell said. "We have a good guy in every weight class."

Some of the Smyrna wrestlers who didn't qualify to make the trip likely would have been competitive, too. That depth makes the top-seeded Eagles the favorite to win the Division I title when Smyrna hosts the DIAA Dual Meet championships on Tuesday night.

"Just in the last week of practice, I had five real emotional and close wrestle-offs that ended up as one-point matches," Howell said. "That's a deep team when you get that. It's a balanced team."

Six Smyrna wrestlers reached the finals, with three – Chase Archangelo (113), Ronnie Wuest (170) and Marquelle Bennett (195) claiming Henlopen crowns.

Wuest edged Lake Forest's Brian Thomson 3-2 in the Milford Invitational in December, but the rematch was more decisive. Wuest got off to a better start and scored a 9-3 decision this time.

"He's not in our division, so you wrestle him once or maybe twice a season," Wuest said of Thomson. "He could be practicing just for a moment like this.

"I was telling myself, 'Go out there and act like you want to dominate the whole match.' I can't just wait until the third period like I always do to rack up points."

In addition to Stevens, Andrew Schmeusser (120), Josh Price (132) and Mark Mullnack (220) won for Polytech. Schmeusser, a senior, met Smyrna sophomore Cole Sebastianelli for the first time in his final and grinded out a 5-0 decision.

"I was just pushing the pace, keeping the intensity up and trying to control every position," Schmeusser said. "You can watch him, but until you wrestle him you don't really know what he feels like. I had to feel him out."

Lucas Monson of Woodbridge was named the tournament's outstanding wrestler after edging Sussex Central's Justin Bennett 3-2 in the 152-pound final, the final match of the day. The Blue Raiders also got a title from Tyreq Nelson at 145.

Two finals were decided by injury default. Cape Henlopen's J.J. Currie and Smyrna's Eli Hutchinson were tied at 2 in the second period at 160 pounds when Hutchinson was injured. CR's Mason Harrington led Milford's Cameron Hayes 6-0 in the third period at 106 when Hayes could no longer continue.

Milford's Bart Dalious (138), CR's Michael Clavier (182) and Dover's Isaiah Abrams (285) also won. The top six finishers in each weight class qualified for the DIAA Individual meet, to be held next Friday and Saturday at Cape Henlopen High. So work remains to be done.

"It was a good fight. I loved it," Abrams said after his tense, 2-1 win over CR's Troy McNally in triple overtime. "And now it's back to the drawing board on Monday."

search_result.text:
NEWARK – Salesianum had a height advantage at every position on Saturday night.

It came in handy during the final minute of the championship game of the DIAA Boys Basketball Tournament.

Isaiah Hynson, the Sals’ 6-foot-4 guard, drove for the last of his 20 points to build a three-point lead with 26 seconds left. Then 6-foot-3 R.J. Johnson heavily pressured William Penn’s final shot to preserve a 48-44 victory at the Carpenter Center.

search_result.title: Milford adds to — but also ends — DIAA Division II wrestling dynasty
search_result.text:
SMYRNA – The Milford High wrestling dynasty continued in dominant fashion but also came to a glorious end on Saturday afternoon inside the Smyrna High gym.

The Buccaneers won their sixth straight Division II championship in the 27th annual DIAA Wrestling Team Championships with a 37-30 victory over Caravel Academy in the title match.

It wasn’t that close as Jack Thode’s major decision at 120 pounds gave Milford an insurmountable lead with four bouts left, three of which Milford forfeited.
